Authenticate: Require authentication for specific website categories.
Warn: Display a warning message but allow users to continue to the website.
Override: Allow users with valid credentials to override their web filter profile.

comments.content: You are absolutely correct. Given the info in the exhibit, Firewall would need to block the initial attempt and produce a warning. Once you accept the warning, then it will allow traffic.

Theres no Warning option available at policy level, its only available at WebFilter level (the only options for policy action are deny or allow). Authenticate and Warning at the same in the way that they produce a warning log first, and then a passtrough log.

The correct option is B.
Correction: The wording on the answers makes C wrong but then there is no correct answer. C would have to be something like "Webfilter category is set to action Warning"

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
There absolutely is a warning action on Webfilter! C is correct, the user receives the warning page because of the webfilter category and proceeds to the website.

choices.C: The action on firewall policy ID 1 is set to warning.

choices.A: The name of the firewall policy is all_users_web.
choices.B: Social networking web filter category is configured with the action set to authenticate.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABD
Study Guide – Routing – Diagnostics – Packet Capture Verbosity Level.

# diagnose sniffer packet <interface> ‘<filter>’ <verbosity> <count> <timestamp> <frame size>

In the example, verbosity is 5.

The verbosity level specifies how much info you want to display.

1 (default): IP Headers.
2: IP Headers, Packet Payload.
3. IP Headers, Packet Payload, Ethernet Headers.
4: IP Headers, Interface Name.
5: IP Headers, Packet Payload, Interface Name.
6: IP Headers, Packet Payload, Ethernet Headers, Interface Name.

Selected Answer: ABD
Correct:
 A. Interface name
 B. IP header
 D. Packet payload

FortiGate Infrastructure 7.2 Study Guide (p.60-61)

Reference and study guide download:
https://ebin.pub/qdownload/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Correct answer 
A, D & E
answer: Interface name, IP header and Packet payload
Infrastructure Guide Page 57

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An administrator has configured a performance SLA on FortiGate, which failed to generate any traffic.
Why is FortiGate not sending probes to 4.2.2.2 and 4.2.2.1 servers? (Choose two.)

choices.A: The Detection Mode setting is not set to Passive.
choices.D: The Enable probe packets setting is not enabled.
choices.C: The configured participants are not SD-WAN members.
choices.B: Administrator didn't configure a gateway for the SD-WAN members, or configured gateway is not valid.

questions.question_text: Which three criteria can a FortiGate use to look for a matching firewall policy to process traffic? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Services defined in the firewall policy.
choices.C: Source defined as Internet Services in the firewall policy.
choices.E: Destination defined as Internet Services in the firewall policy.
choices.D: Lowest to highest policy ID number.
choices.A: Highest to lowest priority defined in the firewall policy.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCE
When a packet arrives, how does FortiGate find a matching policy? Each policy has match criteria, which 
you can define using the following objects:
• Incoming Interface
• Outgoing Interface
• Source: IP address, user, internet services
• Destination: IP address or internet services
• Service: IP protocol and port number
• Schedule: Applies during configured times

Selected Answer: BCE
BCE are Correct

Selected Answer: BCE

Q seems to be asking 'Policy Matching Criteria" not "Order of Policy Matching" and 
Security 7.0 guide pg 110 shows ' Policy has match criteria ... '
- incoming interface
- outgoing interface
- Source
- Destination
- Service 
- Schedule
BCE is correct: https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/fortinet/view/49228-exam-nse4_fgt-64-topic-1-question-20-discussion/
